events.title: 1900 Boxer Rebellion intervention
events.summary: An eight-nation alliance (including future NATO founders US, UK, France, Germany) militarily intervenes in China to crush a nationalist uprising, previewing Western power projection.
events.punchline: A dress rehearsal for a century of Western-led coalitions.

events.title: 1901 US Steel Corporation formed
events.summary: J.P. Morgan creates the world's first billion-dollar corporation, centralizing the industrial muscle that will power two World Wars and a Cold War.
events.punchline: Forging the arsenal of democracy, one monopoly at a time.

events.title: 1900 German Naval Law passed
events.summary: Germany dramatically expands its Imperial Navy, directly challenging British naval supremacy and forcing the UK to look for allies (like France).
events.punchline: Wilhelm II starts the arms race that his successors would lose twice.

events.title: 1900 McKinley re-elected (Roosevelt VP)
events.summary: President McKinley's victory ensures pro-industrial, expansionist foreign policy. His new VP, Theodore Roosevelt, would become a foundational figure of American global power.
events.punchline: The 'big stick' is waiting in the wings.

events.title: 1900 Planck's Quantum Theory
events.summary: Max Planck proposes quantum theory in Berlin, unknowingly starting the scientific revolution that will lead to the ultimate weapon and the nuclear deterrent at NATO's core.
events.punchline: A lecture in Berlin plants the seed for the Bomb that would end a war and define the next.

events.title: 1900 British Labour Party founded
events.summary: The formation of a party that would go on to lead Britain into NATO and be a key transatlantic partner, balancing US power within the alliance.
events.punchline: The future left-wing pillar of the Atlantic Alliance gets its start.

events.title: 1900 First Zeppelin flight
events.summary: Count von Zeppelin's rigid airship takes its first flight, pioneering a technology that would be used for bombing raids in WWI and later for transatlantic travel concepts.
events.punchline: The first step towards strategic bombing and the need to defend against it.

events.title: 1900 Hague Convention comes into force
events.summary: An early attempt to create laws of war and arms control, a principle NATO would later have to navigate constantly.
events.punchline: Writing the rulebook for the wars everyone knew were coming.

events.title: 1900 Paris Metro opens
events.summary: A symbol of modern national infrastructure and industrial organization, the kind of logistical capability that would be essential for mobilizing a continental army.
events.punchline: Building the home front, one subway line at a time.

events.title: 1900 Britain consolidates control in South Africa
events.summary: The brutal Second Boer War continues, demonstrating the scale of imperial power that would be a cornerstone of the West's global strength for the next half-century.
events.punchline: Pax Britannica: securing the resources and routes for a future Pax Americana.

events.title: 1901 Queen Victoria dies
events.summary: The end of an era. Her grandson, Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany, and her grandson, King George V of Britain, now rule Europe's two most powerful nations, setting the stage for a family feud with global consequences.
events.punchline: The matriarch of Europe dies, and her squabbling grandchildren prepare for war.

events.title: 1901 First Nobel Peace Prize awarded
events.summary: The prize goes to Henri Dunant, founder of the Red Cross, establishing an ideal of humanitarian law that NATO missions would later struggle to uphold.
events.punchline: A lofty goal set just before the most violent century in history.

events.title: 1901 Theodore Roosevelt becomes President
events.summary: After McKinley's assassination, the energetic expansionist takes office. His 'big stick' diplomacy and focus on a strong navy become permanent features of US foreign policy.
events.punchline: The architect of the American Century gets his desk.

events.title: 1901 Marconi sends first transatlantic radio signal
events.summary: The first wireless signal crosses the Atlantic from Cornwall to Newfoundland, revolutionizing communication and future command & control for a global alliance.
events.punchline: Shrinking the ocean that the Atlantic Alliance would name itself after.

events.title: 1901 US Army War College founded
events.summary: Established to teach strategy and advanced military studies, it would become a key institution for training the American officers who would lead NATO commands.
events.punchline: The school for the future SHAPE commanders opens its doors.

events.title: 1901 Hay-Pauncefote Treaty signed
events.summary: UK gives US sole right to build and defend a canal in Central America, signaling the transfer of hemispheric hegemony from Britain to the United States.
events.punchline: The 'special relationship' begins with Britain politely handing over the keys.

events.title: 1901 Socialist International meets
events.summary: European socialist parties gather, promoting international worker solidarity—an ideological challenge to the nationalist imperial order that would eventually be countered by Western unity.
events.punchline: The other internationalism: one of class, soon to be overshadowed by one of blocs.

events.title: 1901 US Navy commissions its first submarine
events.summary: USS Holland (SS-1) enters service, pioneering a weapon system that would become a critical, stealthy pillar of NATO's nuclear deterrent strategy.
events.punchline: The silent service begins, destined to carry the world's most powerful weapons.

events.title: 1901 Anglo-Japanese Alliance negotiations begin
events.summary: Britain seeks an ally in the Pacific to counter Russian and German influence, a realpolitik move that foreshadows its future strategy of building alliances against rising threats.
events.punchline: Britain's playbook: if you can't beat 'em, ally with someone who can.

events.title: 1901 President McKinley assassinated
events.summary: The murder of the US President by an anarchist highlights the emerging threat of political extremism and instability that would plague the century.
events.punchline: A violent preview of the ideological chaos that would require a defensive alliance to contain.

events.title: Treaty of Versailles
events.summary: Post-WWI settlement reshapes European borders and security.
events.punchline: Peace terms with a timer.

events.title: League of Nations formed
events.summary: First intergovernmental organization for collective security.
events.punchline: Version 0.9 of 'an attack on one...'

events.title: World War II begins
events.summary: Germany invades Poland; global war follows.
events.punchline: Patch notes for human history get ugly.

events.title: United Nations founded
events.summary: International organization for peace and cooperation is established.
events.punchline: Peace, but with a Security Council speed limiter.

events.title: Marshall Plan launched
events.summary: U.S. economic aid to rebuild Western Europe.
events.punchline: Money printer goes brrr—for democracy.

events.title: Truman Doctrine announced
events.summary: U.S. commits to support nations resisting coercion.
events.punchline: Foreign policy: 'no free lunches for bullies' edition.

events.title: Brussels Treaty signed
events.summary: Western European Union mutual defense pact among five states.
events.punchline: Logistics: 1. Block the roads. 2. Watch the skies.

events.title: North Atlantic Treaty signed
events.summary: Twelve nations create a collective defense alliance.
events.punchline: Article 5 enters the chat.

events.title: Korean War begins
events.summary: NATO coordinates strategic responses though not a NATO operation.
events.punchline: UN op, NATO brains online.

events.title: Greece and Türkiye join
events.summary: Alliance enlarges to 14 members.
events.punchline: Mediterranean DLC unlocked.

events.title: Warsaw Pact formed
events.summary: Soviet-led counter-alliance to NATO.
events.punchline: Mirror alliance equipped with 'copy strategy' perk.

events.title: West Germany joins NATO
events.summary: Integration of West Germany into Western defense.
events.punchline: From adversary to ally speedrun.

events.title: France withdraws from NATO’s integrated command
events.summary: National decision to leave integrated military structure.
events.punchline: BRB, strategic autonomy.

events.title: Harmel Report adopted
events.summary: Dual-track approach: defense + détente.
events.punchline: Peace through strength—plus coffee diplomacy.

events.title: NATO HQ moves to Brussels
events.summary: Alliance headquarters relocates from Paris to Brussels.
events.punchline: Central server migrated.

events.title: Spain joins NATO
events.summary: Membership expands on the Iberian Peninsula.
events.punchline: Tapas added to the mess hall.

events.title: CFE Treaty signed
events.summary: Conventional Armed Forces in Europe limitations agreed.
events.punchline: Cold War hardware gets a diet.

events.title: USSR dissolves
events.summary: End of the Cold War reshapes European security.
events.punchline: Final boss defeated by internal bugs.

events.title: Partnership for Peace launched
events.summary: Cooperative program with non-member states.
events.punchline: Friends list opens.

events.title: IFOR in Bosnia and Herzegovina
events.summary: NATO-led peace implementation force deployed.
events.punchline: Peacekeeping with teeth.

events.title: Kosovo air campaign
events.summary: NATO conducts Operation Allied Force.
events.punchline: No-fly meets no-chill.

events.title: Poland, Czechia, Hungary join
events.summary: First post–Cold War enlargement.
events.punchline: Eastward expansion level 1.

events.title: Article 5 invoked (9/11)
events.summary: Collective defense triggered for the first time.
events.punchline: The clause isn’t decorative.

events.title: NATO assumes ISAF command (Afghanistan)
events.summary: Stabilization mission under UN mandate.
events.punchline: Nation-building on hard mode.

events.title: Seven countries join
events.summary: Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia.
events.punchline: Enlargement speedrun PB.

events.title: Albania and Croatia join
events.summary: Further Balkan integration.
events.punchline: Adriatic secure, barbershop approved.

events.title: Libya intervention
events.summary: NATO enforces UN-authorized no-fly zone.
events.punchline: When 'air superiority' is the whole story.

events.title: Montenegro joins NATO
events.summary: Alliance grows to 29.
events.punchline: Small country, big veto power.

events.title: North Macedonia joins NATO
events.summary: Name dispute resolution enables accession.
events.punchline: One adjective later—door opens.

events.title: Finland joins NATO
events.summary: Border with Russia that actually answers back.
events.punchline: 2,600 km of 'try me'.

events.title: Sweden joins NATO
events.summary: Longstanding non-aligned state becomes member.
events.punchline: From neutrality to 'nah'.

events.title: 1905 Russian Revolution of 1905
events.summary: Widespread unrest, sparked by Bloody Sunday and war losses, forces the Tsar to create a parliament (Duma). This first crack in the Tsarist autocracy paves the way for 1917.
events.punchline: The first tremor of the earthquake that would swallow the Russian Empire.

events.title: 1905 Einstein's 'Miracle Year'
events.summary: An unknown patent clerk publishes papers on special relativity, photoelectric effect, and Brownian motion, revolutionizing physics and setting the course for the atomic age.
events.punchline: The equations that would unlock the nucleus—and unleash hell—are written in peace.

events.title: 1905 Treaty of Portsmouth ends Russo-Japanese War
events.summary: US President Theodore Roosevelt brokers peace, winning a Nobel Prize and establishing America as a global mediator and Pacific power.
events.punchline: America steps onto the world stage not with a gun, but with a negotiating table.

events.title: 1905 Norway gains full independence from Sweden
events.summary: A peaceful dissolution of the union creates a new sovereign state that will later become a founding member of NATO.
events.punchline: A peaceful divorce creates a future guardian of the North Atlantic.

events.title: 1905 First Moroccan Crisis
events.summary: Kaiser Wilhelm II visits Tangier, challenging French influence and testing the new Entente Cordiale. The crisis pushes Britain closer to France.
events.punchline: The Kaiser on a white horse, poking the Entente to see if it's real. It was.

events.title: 1905 Mutiny on the Battleship Potemkin
events.summary: Sailors of the Russian Black Sea Fleet rebel over poor conditions, a famous symbol of the revolutionary unrest sweeping Russia and a warning to all empires about troop loyalty.
events.punchline: A warship becomes a floating commune, terrifying admirals everywhere.

events.title: 1905 First formal sniper training program
events.summary: The German army establishes the first dedicated school for scoped marksmanship, recognizing the increasing importance of precision, long-range fire in modern warfare.
events.punchline: Warfare gets a scope, and the battlefield becomes exponentially more dangerous.

events.title: 1905 Karlstad Convention formalizes Norway-Sweden split
events.summary: The treaty peacefully dissolves the union between Sweden and Norway, preventing war and establishing a precedent for diplomatic conflict resolution in Scandinavia.
events.punchline: A masterclass in how to break up a kingdom without breaking any windows.

events.title: 1905 Germany launches its first U-boat, U-1
events.summary: The Imperial German Navy commissions its first submarine, a weapon that would define naval warfare in both World Wars and shape Atlantic strategy.
events.punchline: The predator that would force the Allies to invent sonar and convoys is launched.

events.title: 1905 UK Aliens Act passed
events.summary: In response to Jewish refugees fleeing pogroms, Britain passes its first law restricting immigration, reflecting a turn towards nationalism and border control.
events.punchline: The island fortress begins to draw up the drawbridge.

events.title: 1905 First radio broadcast from a ship at sea
events.summary: The US Navy experiments with transmitting music and speech from a vessel, testing the potential for ship-to-ship and ship-to-shore entertainment and communication.
events.punchline: The lonely life of a sailor gets a little less lonely, thanks to wireless.

events.title: 1905 First practical gyrocompass demonstrated
events.summary: German inventor Hermann Anschütz-Kaempfe demonstrates a compass that points to true north, unaffected by metal, revolutionizing naval navigation.
events.punchline: Ships finally know exactly where they are, which is the first step to knowing where to shoot.

events.title: 1905 Ottoman-Persian Frontier Treaty
events.summary: The Ottoman Empire and Persia (Iran) demarcate their border, creating a line that would later become the contentious Iraq-Iran border.
events.punchline: Drawing a line in the sand that would be fought over for the next 100 years.

events.title: 1905 First medical examination of pilots
events.summary: The US Army Signal Corps, anticipating the military use of aircraft, begins assessing the physical fitness of potential pilots, creating the concept of aircrew medicine.
events.punchline: Figuring out what kind of human can survive in the air, before there's an air force.

events.title: 1905 Sinn Féin political party founded
events.summary: The Irish nationalist party is established, beginning a long political and eventually paramilitary struggle that would create a neutral Republic of Ireland outside of NATO.
events.punchline: The birth of a movement that would ensure a NATO member has a neutral neighbor.

events.title: 1905 Wright Flyer III becomes first practical airplane
events.summary: The Wright brothers achieve sustained, controlled flight, making the airplane a viable technology. They immediately offer it to the US War Department.
events.punchline: The toy becomes a tool, and the sky becomes a battlefield.

events.title: 1905 First international wildlife conservation treaty
events.summary: European powers sign a treaty to protect African birds useful to agriculture, an early example of international cooperation on non-military issues.
events.punchline: Nations can agree on saving birds long before they can agree on saving themselves.

events.title: 1905 British Royal Engineers balloon corps expanded
events.summary: The UK invests more in its military balloon unit, recognizing the growing importance of aerial reconnaissance for artillery spotting and intelligence.
events.punchline: The eyes in the sky get a bigger budget.

events.title: 1905 First patent for a practical gas turbine
events.summary: Frenchman Armengaud Lemale patents a design for a continuous-combustion engine, a key step towards the jet engines that would power NATO's air supremacy.
events.punchline: The quiet birth of the scream that would define 20th-century air power.

events.title: 1905 Taft–Katsura Agreement
events.summary: The US and Japan secretly agree on spheres of influence: US acknowledges Japanese control over Korea, Japan disavows interest in the Philippines.
events.punchline: Imperial powers trade colonies like baseball cards, setting the stage for future conflict.

events.title: 1903 US backs Panamanian independence
events.summary: Theodore Roosevelt supports a revolt against Colombia to secure rights to build the Panama Canal, a masterclass in gunboat diplomacy and securing strategic global chokepoints.
events.punchline: Creating a country for a canal—the ultimate infrastructure project.

events.title: 1903 First powered, controlled flight
events.summary: The Wright Flyer takes off at Kitty Hawk, unlocking the domain of air power that would dominate 20th-century warfare and become NATO's primary battleground.
events.punchline: The first 12-second hop towards strategic bombing and air superiority.

events.title: 1903 UK Royal College of Defence Studies founded
events.summary: Established as the Imperial Defence College, it begins training senior officers and officials in grand strategy, creating the future architects of British and NATO policy.
events.punchline: The school for the masters of the chessboard opens its doors.

events.title: 1903 First complete transatlantic radio message
events.summary: Marconi establishes a commercial wireless service between US and UK, making near-instant communication across the ocean a reality—the nervous system of a future alliance.
events.punchline: Shrinking the Atlantic, one Morse code click at a time.

events.title: 1903 Russian Social Democrats split
events.summary: The party fractures into Bolsheviks (Lenin) and Mensheviks, formalizing the split that will lead to the creation of the Soviet Union—NATO's future raison d'être.
events.punchline: At a party congress in exile, the seeds of the Cold War are sown.

events.title: 1903 French Aigrette submarine launched
events.summary: The world's first diesel-powered submarine is commissioned, a key technological leap in stealth naval warfare that would define the Battle of the Atlantic.
events.punchline: Quieter, deadlier, and harder to find—the perfect naval predator is born.

events.title: 1903 US Army War College relocates to D.C.
events.summary: The key strategic institution moves to Washington D.C., placing it at the heart of political and military power, where it would shape American strategy for decades.
events.punchline: Strategy moves from the classroom to the corridors of power.

events.title: 1903 First Tour de France
events.summary: The grueling race is created to boost sales for a newspaper, but becomes a symbol of national endurance and pride—the kind of soft power that underpins alliances.
events.punchline: Building national spirit, one painful pedal stroke at a time.

events.title: 1903 Alaska Boundary Dispute settled
events.summary: An international tribunal resolves a tense US-Canada-UK border dispute, proving that Anglo-American diplomatic channels could peacefully resolve issues that might otherwise lead to conflict.
events.punchline: Neighbors learn to settle arguments without shooting—a useful skill for an alliance.

events.title: 1903 First successful diesel engine for ships
events.summary: The Russian tanker Vandal is launched, the first ship with a diesel-engine and electric transmission, revolutionizing maritime logistics and future naval propulsion.
events.punchline: Making the world smaller and the business of war more efficient.

events.title: 1903 'The Great Train Robbery' released
events.summary: This pioneering American film creates the archetype of the Western, mythologizing the expansion and individualism that defined the US character on the world stage.
events.punchline: America begins exporting its founding myth to the world.

events.title: 1903 First use of radium for therapy
events.summary: Marie Curie promotes the use of radium to treat tumors, a medical breakthrough born from the same radioactive science that would soon create the ultimate weapon.
events.punchline: The atom learns to heal, before it is taught to destroy.

events.title: 1903 IBM predecessor founded
events.summary: The Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (CTR) is formed, which will become IBM—the company that will provide the data processing backbone for the US war effort and beyond.
events.punchline: The paperwork for future armies gets a machine to manage it.

events.title: 1903 First automobile crosses the USA
events.summary: A Packard motor car completes the two-month journey, demonstrating the potential of the internal combustion engine for mobility and future military logistics.
events.punchline: Proving a continent could be conquered without horses or railroads.

events.title: 1903 First international doping ban in sports
events.summary: The IOC discusses banning performance-enhancing drugs, an early recognition of chemical augmentation that would later have parallels in military enhancement research.
events.punchline: The quest for a superhuman soldier begins with trying to stop a superhuman cyclist.

events.title: 1903 US 'Great White Fleet' visits Mediterranean
events.summary: Roosevelt sends a battleship squadron on a global tour, a bold projection of American naval power into what had been a European-dominated sphere.
events.punchline: America's new, white business card: a fleet of battleships.

events.title: 1903 US Forest Service established
events.summary: The federal agency is created to manage natural resources, reflecting a growing understanding of strategic resource management—a national security concern.
events.punchline: Realizing that national strength requires managing more than just armies.

events.title: 1903 First international air show
events.summary: The Paris Air Show begins, immediately becoming a marketplace for military aviation technology and a stage for national competition.
events.punchline: Where future aces and arms dealers meet to make deals.

events.title: 1903 First major oil pipeline in Middle East
events.summary: The pipeline from Iranian oil fields to the Persian Gulf begins operation, inaugurating the energy infrastructure that would dictate global strategy for the next century.
events.punchline: The first vein of the lifeblood of modern warfare is tapped.

events.title: 1903 First modern World Series
events.summary: The American and National baseball leagues hold their first championship, creating a national cultural event that would help unify the American home front during future conflicts.
events.punchline: Building a national identity, one inning at a time.

events.title: 1907 Anglo-Russian Entente signed
events.summary: Britain and Russia settle their colonial disputes in Asia, completing the Triple Entente with France. The two opposing blocs of WWI are now clearly defined.
events.punchline: The final piece of the puzzle locks into place. The stage for the Great War is set.

events.title: 1911 Churchill switches Navy to oil
events.summary: UK First Lord of Admiralty Winston Churchill commits fleet to oil, not coal, tying Western security to Middle East forever.
events.punchline: The first domino for 100 years of intervention.

events.title: 1914 Archduke Franz Ferdinand assassinated
events.summary: A single bullet in Sarajevo triggers the alliance chains, plunging Europe into war.
events.punchline: The original 'Article 5' test—and it worked too well.

events.title: 1914 Archduke Franz Ferdinand assassinated
events.summary: Gavrilo Princip, a Bosnian Serb nationalist, shoots and kills the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne in Sarajevo. The event triggers the July Crisis and the start of WWI.
events.punchline: A single bullet in a provincial capital starts the clock on the death of millions.

events.title: 1914 Austria-Hungary issues July Ultimatum
events.summary: With German backing, Austria-Hungary presents Serbia with a list of ten deliberately unacceptable demands, setting the stage for a 'local' war meant to punish Serbia.
events.punchline: An empire sends a document designed to be rejected, because it wants an excuse for war.

events.title: 1914 Russia orders general mobilization
events.summary: In support of fellow Slavs in Serbia, Tsar Nicholas II orders the mobilization of the Russian army. Germany views this as an act of war.
events.punchline: The Russian bear lumbers to its feet, and the German eagle sees its moment to strike.

events.title: 1914 Germany declares war on Russia
events.summary: Invoking the Schlieffen Plan, Germany declares war on Russia, believing a wider European conflict is now inevitable and seeking to strike first.
events.punchline: The first formal declaration of the Great War. The dominoes begin to fall with mathematical precision.

events.title: 1914 Germany invades Belgium
events.summary: To execute the Schlieffen Plan and attack France from the north, German forces violate Belgian neutrality, the act that brings Britain into the war.
events.punchline: A 'scrap of paper' (the treaty guaranteeing Belgian neutrality) becomes the reason the world's largest empire goes to war.

events.title: 1914 Britain declares war on Germany
events.summary: Following the invasion of Belgium, the British Empire, including Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, enters the war against Germany.
events.punchline: The sun never sets on the British Empire, and now it never sets on a world at war.

events.title: 1914 First Battle of the Marne
events.summary: French and British forces halt the German advance just 30 miles from Paris in a desperate counterattack. The Schlieffen Plan fails, and the war of movement ends.
events.punchline: The German drive for a quick victory is stopped by taxi cabs and sheer desperation. The trench deadlock begins.

events.title: 1914 First aerial victory using a weapon
events.summary: Russian pilot Pyotr Nesterov rams an Austrian reconnaissance plane, achieving the first kill in air combat but dying in the process.
events.punchline: Aerial warfare begins not with a gun, but with a suicidal act of desperation.

events.title: 1914 Panama Canal opens
events.summary: The SS Ancon becomes the first ship to transit the canal, a monumental engineering achievement that drastically shortens global shipping routes and US naval response times.
events.punchline: A decade of labor and thousands of lives create the world's most strategic shortcut, just as a world war begins.

events.title: 1914 Christmas Truce
events.summary: Along parts of the Western Front, German, British, and French soldiers spontaneously cease hostilities, exchange gifts, and even play football in no-man's-land.
events.punchline: A fleeting moment of shared humanity proves that the men in the trenches had more in common with each other than with the generals behind the lines.

events.title: 1914 First Battle of Ypres
events.summary: The German and Allied armies clash in Flanders. The battle ends the 'Race to the Sea' and solidifies the continuous trench line from the Swiss border to the North Sea.
events.punchline: The last major mobile battle on the Western Front ends, and the grinding slaughter of trench warfare is locked in place.

events.title: 1914 Ottoman Empire joins Central Powers
events.summary: After a secret alliance and a naval provocation, the Ottomans bombard Russian ports, entering the war and opening new fronts in the Caucasus and the Middle East.
events.punchline: The sick man of Europe enters the war, ensuring his own demise and transforming a European conflict into a world war.

events.title: 1914 Battle of the Falkland Islands
events.summary: The Royal Navy destroys a German cruiser squadron, avenging its defeat at Coronel and asserting British naval supremacy for the rest of the war.
events.punchline: Britannia rules the waves, and proves it by sinking Germany's last hope for a surface fleet abroad.

events.title: 1914 First Zeppelin bombing raid on UK
events.summary: German Zeppelins drop bombs on Great Yarmouth, introducing the world to strategic bombing and the concept of total war against civilian populations.
events.punchline: The front line vanishes. Death now arrives silently from the dark sky onto your own doorstep.

events.title: 1914 US Federal Trade Commission established
events.summary: President Wilson creates the FTC to regulate unfair business practices, an attempt to control the immense economic power that would soon be harnessed for war.
events.punchline: America tries to tame its capitalist engine, not knowing it will soon need to run that engine at full throttle.

events.title: 1914 First issue of 'The New Republic'
events.summary: The influential American liberal magazine is founded, providing a platform for the intellectual debates that would shape US interventionism and post-war ideals.
events.punchline: A new voice for American liberalism is born, just as liberalism in Europe is entering its greatest crisis.

events.title: 1914 Freud publishes 'On Narcissism'
events.summary: Sigmund Freud's work further develops psychoanalytic theory, exploring concepts that would later be used to understand the trauma of shell shock and war neuroses.
events.punchline: The mind's darkest corners are mapped, just as the world is about to give millions of minds a reason to hide in them.

events.title: 1914 First armored car units deployed
events.summary: The Belgian Army uses Minerva armored cars for reconnaissance and hit-and-run attacks, an early, mobile form of the armored warfare to come.
events.punchline: The first practical armored vehicles rumble into battle, a primitive glimpse of the blitzkrieg future.

events.title: 1914 First German colonies fall
events.summary: British and French forces quickly overrun German Togoland and Samoa, showing the vulnerability of Germany's overseas empire and its global isolation.
events.punchline: Germany's modest imperial dream is dismantled before the first leaves fall in Europe.

events.title: 1914 US declares neutrality
events.summary: President Woodrow Wilson formally proclaims American neutrality, a stance that will be tested by German submarine warfare and British propaganda.
events.punchline: America tries to sit out the 'European war,' but the war will not sit out America.

events.title: 1915 Gallipoli Campaign begins
events.summary: British, French, and ANZAC forces launch a disastrous amphibious invasion of the Ottoman Turkish coast, aiming to secure a sea route to Russia. It becomes a bloody stalemate.
events.punchline: A bold plan to break the deadlock turns into a tomb for tens of thousands on a sunny beach.

events.title: 1915 RMS Lusitania sunk by U-boat
events.summary: A German U-boat torpedoes the British ocean liner off Ireland, killing 1,198, including 128 Americans. It massively turns international opinion against Germany.
events.location: Off the coast of Kinsale, Ireland
events.punchline: A single torpedo brings America to the brink of war and proves total war has no civilian boundaries.

events.title: 1915 Second Battle of Ypres: First use of poison gas
events.summary: The German army releases 168 tons of chlorine gas against Allied trenches, violating the Hague Conventions and opening a horrific new chapter in warfare.
events.punchline: The laws of war are dissolved into a green, choking cloud. The battlefield becomes a laboratory of horror.

events.title: 1915 Italy joins the Allies
events.summary: Lured by promises of territorial gains, Italy declares war on Austria-Hungary, opening up the brutal Alpine front and stretching Central Powers resources.
events.punchline: The Allies get a new partner, and the war gets a new meat grinder in the mountains.

events.title: 1915 Armenian Genocide begins
events.summary: The Ottoman government begins the systematic deportation and mass murder of its Armenian population, the first genocide of the 20th century.
events.punchline: A modern government uses war as cover to attempt the annihilation of an ancient people.

events.title: 1915 T.E. Lawrence arrives in Cairo
events.summary: The young British archaeologist and intelligence officer begins his work, which will evolve into fomenting the Arab Revolt against the Ottoman Empire.
events.punchline: A scholar in an army uniform arrives to turn a desert rebellion into a strategic weapon.

events.title: 1915 First Zeppelin raid on London
events.summary: German airships begin bombing the British capital, bringing the war directly to the civilian population of a major world city for the first time.
events.punchline: The sky over London glows with fire, and the concept of the 'home front' is invented.

events.title: 1915 First isolation tank invented
events.summary: Neuropsychiatrist John C. Lilly develops the sensory deprivation tank to study the origin of consciousness—a strange, peaceful invention in a year of unparalleled noise and violence.
events.punchline: A machine designed to create perfect silence is built while the world is learning to scream.

events.title: 1915 US Coast Guard created
events.summary: The Revenue Cutter Service and the Life-Saving Service merge to form the modern Coast Guard, creating a unified service for maritime law and security.
events.punchline: America organizes its watchers of the coast, a service that will soon hunt U-boats.

events.title: 1915 Einstein presents General Relativity
events.summary: The physicist completes his theory of general relativity, fundamentally reshaping human understanding of gravity, space, and time—while humanity engages in its most destructive behavior.
events.punchline: A mind in Berlin bends the universe to mathematics, while the city's army tries to bend Europe to its will.

events.title: 1915 Allied propaganda efforts intensify
events.summary: Britain and France establish sophisticated propaganda bureaus to control the narrative of the war, demonize the enemy, and influence neutral opinion (especially in the USA).
events.punchline: The truth becomes the first casualty, systematically dismantled by professional storytellers in government offices.

events.title: 1915 British advance in Mesopotamia
events.summary: Indian Army troops under British command advance towards Baghdad to secure Persian oil fields, a campaign that will end in disastrous defeat at Kut.
events.punchline: The British Empire marches for oil, a strategic resource that now dictates military campaigns.

events.title: 1915 First transatlantic voice radio transmission
events.summary: AT&T engineers successfully transmit the human voice from Virginia to Paris, a leap in communications technology with immense future military potential.
events.punchline: A voice crosses the ocean without a wire, a technology that will one day command D-Day armadas.

events.title: 1915 First tank prototype ('Little Willie') tested
events.summary: The British Landship Committee tests its first armored tracked vehicle, a desperate attempt to break the stalemate of the trenches.
events.punchline: A clumsy, steel box on tracks lumbers across a test field, the answer to a million miles of barbed wire.

events.title: 1915 UK expands Defence of the Realm Act (DORA)
events.summary: The British government grants itself sweeping powers to control industry, censor media, and regulate daily life, creating a template for the total war state.
events.punchline: Parliament voluntarily gives away its freedoms, deciding you can't have both democracy and victory in a total war.

events.title: 1915 Lettow-Vorbeck's guerrilla campaign begins
events.summary: German Colonel Paul von Lettow-Vorbeck begins a brilliant guerrilla campaign in East Africa, tying down hundreds of thousands of Allied troops with his small force.
events.location: Dar es Salaam, German East Africa
events.punchline: A German officer fights a masterful losing battle in the jungle, a four-year lesson in asymmetric warfare.

events.title: 1915 First use of sodium citrate as anticoagulant
events.summary: Dr. Richard Lewisohn discovers that sodium citrate prevents blood from coagulating, making blood transfusion practical and saving countless future lives on and off the battlefield.
events.punchline: A doctor finds a way to stop blood from clotting, unlocking the ability to pour life directly from one person into another.

events.title: 1915 Bulgaria joins Central Powers
events.summary: Lured by promises of Macedonian territory, Bulgaria declares war on Serbia, effectively sealing Serbia's fate and opening a new, brutal front.
events.punchline: The last major power picks a side, and the Balkans are once again drenched in blood.

events.title: 1915 Gorlice-Tarnów Offensive
events.summary: A German-led offensive on the Eastern Front shatters Russian lines, resulting in a massive 'Great Retreat' that costs Russia huge territories and casualties.
events.punchline: The German war machine demonstrates its brutal efficiency in the east, pushing the Russian army to the brink of collapse.

events.title: 1915 'Munitionettes' enter UK workforce
events.summary: With men at the front, hundreds of thousands of British women take jobs in munitions factories, a crucial and dangerous contribution that permanently changes their role in society.
events.punchline: Women leave the kitchen to make the explosives that will destroy a generation of men.

events.title: 1916 Battle of Verdun begins
events.summary: The German Army launches a massive offensive against the symbolic French fortress. Their strategy: 'bleed the French army white.' The resulting 10-month battle becomes the longest and one of the most devastating of the war.
events.punchline: A battle not to win territory, but to exterminate an army. The arithmetic of slaughter becomes strategy.

events.title: 1916 Battle of the Somme begins
events.summary: The British Army launches its own massive offensive to relieve pressure on Verdun. The first day remains the bloodiest in British military history, with 57,000 casualties.
events.punchline: A volunteer army is fed into the fire on its first day. The idealism of 1914 dies in the mud of Picardy.

events.title: 1916 First use of tanks in battle
events.summary: The British Mark I tank makes its combat debut at the Somme. Though mechanically unreliable and few in number, they reveal the potential of a war-winning weapon.
events.punchline: A steel monster crawls out of the industrial nightmare and into the German trenches, sowing pure terror.

events.title: 1916 Battle of Jutland
events.summary: The British Grand Fleet and German High Seas Fleet clash in the North Sea. It is the largest naval battle of the war. Both sides claim victory, but the British maintain their strategic blockade.
events.punchline: Two giant fleets spend an afternoon trying to destroy each other, and then never speak of it again.

events.title: 1916 Easter Rising in Dublin
events.summary: Irish republicans launch an armed insurrection against British rule, proclaiming an Irish Republic. The brutal British response turns public opinion in favor of independence.
events.punchline: While Britain fights for empire abroad, a rebellion breaks out at its very core.

events.title: 1916 Brusilov Offensive
events.summary: Russian General Alexei Brusilov launches a surprise attack against Austria-Hungary, achieving the most successful Russian advance of the war and crippling the Austro-Hungarian army.
events.punchline: The Russian steamroller finally works, but the cost in blood ensures it will be the last time.

events.title: 1916 Arab Revolt begins
events.summary: Sharif Hussein of Mecca launches a revolt against Ottoman rule, aided by the UK and T.E. Lawrence. It opens a new front and secures the Suez Canal.
events.punchline: The desert itself rises up against the Ottomans, led by a British archaeologist in a white robe.

events.title: 1916 UK introduces conscription
events.summary: After the losses of 1915, Britain passes the Military Service Act, mandating conscription for single men. The volunteer era is over; the state now demands its citizens' lives.
events.punchline: Your country doesn't ask for your life anymore; it tells you to hand it over.

events.title: 1916 Sykes-Picot Agreement signed
events.summary: Britain and France secretly agree to divide the Ottoman Empire's Middle Eastern territories into spheres of influence, creating the modern borders of the region and ignoring promises made to Arabs.
events.punchline: Two diplomats in a room draw lines on a map that will define a century of conflict.

events.title: 1916 First fighter squadrons formed
events.summary: Both sides organize aircraft into dedicated fighter squadrons, like Germany's 'Jastas,' led by aces like Manfred von Richthofen. Aerial warfare becomes organized and deadlier.
events.punchline: The lonely knights of the air become a coordinated pack of hunters.

events.title: 1916 US National Defense Act
events.summary: Congress significantly expands the size of the US Army and National Guard and establishes the Reserve Officer Training Corps (ROTC), preparing the nation for potential involvement.
events.punchline: America, while still neutral, starts building the framework for an army of millions.

events.title: 1916 David Lloyd George becomes UK PM
events.summary: The energetic and ruthless Welshman replaces the faltering H.H. Asquith, vowing to pursue the war with greater vigor and coordination among the Allies.
events.punchline: A man who knows the price of shells and the value of blood takes the wheel.

events.title: 1916 Germany decides on unrestricted submarine warfare
events.summary: Facing starvation and stalemate, the German High Command decides to resume sinking all ships heading to Britain, a gamble to strangle the UK before the US can react.
events.punchline: Germany bets its empire that it can starve Britain into surrender before America can mobilize.

events.title: 1916 US ends occupation of Veracruz
events.summary: After two years, American troops withdraw from the Mexican port city, a small de-escalation on the southern flank as the European war demands more attention.
events.punchline: America decides it only has the capacity for one hemisphere-sized problem at a time.

events.title: 1916 Lewis Gun becomes standard issue
events.summary: The lightweight, air-cooled Lewis gun is widely issued to British troops, dramatically increasing the firepower of the infantry squad.
events.punchline: Every squad gets its own personal waterfall of lead.

events.title: 1916 The era of the 'ace' begins
events.summary: The term 'ace' for a pilot with five confirmed kills is popularized. Men like Max Immelmann and Oswald Boelcke become national heroes, providing a romantic facade for the industrial slaughter below.
events.punchline: Nations invent chivalrous heroes in the sky to distract from the anonymous death in the mud.

events.title: 1916 Widespread deployment of anti-aircraft guns
events.summary: As aerial bombing increases, both sides deploy specialized artillery designed to shoot at aircraft, creating a new branch of warfare: air defense.
events.punchline: The sky is no longer a sanctuary. Now even the clouds can shoot back.

events.title: 1916 Pancho Villa raids New Mexico
events.summary: The Mexican revolutionary attacks the town of Columbus, killing Americans. The US responds with the Punitive Expedition, led by General Pershing, into Mexico.
events.punchline: A minor border skirmish that gives the US Army a taste of expeditionary warfare before the main course in France.

events.title: 1916 First concepts for a jet engine patented
events.summary: English engineer Alan Arnold Griffith publishes a groundbreaking paper on turbine design, laying the theoretical foundation for the jet engine.
events.punchline: In an office far from the front, a man draws the future of flight on paper, while biplanes duel overhead.

events.title: 1916 Rasputin is murdered
events.summary: Russian aristocrats, fearing the mystic's influence over the Tsarina, brutally assassinate him. His death removes a key pillar of support for the crumbling Tsarist regime.
events.punchline: The 'mad monk' is finally killed, but the disease rotting the heart of the Russian Empire is far more terminal.

events.title: 1917 United States declares war on Germany
events.summary: After repeated provocations, including unrestricted submarine warfare and the Zimmermann Telegram, the U.S. joins the Allies in World War I.
events.punchline: America joins the meat grinder—late, but with fresh legs and deep pockets.

events.title: 1917 Zimmermann Telegram revealed
events.summary: British intelligence intercepts a German proposal to Mexico to join the war against the U.S., helping sway American public opinion toward intervention.
events.punchline: Germany tries to recruit Mexico for a border war—Britain leaks the plot like a Netflix trailer.

events.title: 1917 Russian February Revolution
events.summary: Mass protests and mutinies force Tsar Nicholas II to abdicate, ending centuries of Romanov rule and creating a provisional government.
events.punchline: The empire collapses under its own weight—no bullets needed, just bread riots and broken promises.

events.title: 1917 Bolsheviks seize power in Russia
events.summary: Lenin and the Bolsheviks overthrow the provisional government, establishing a communist regime and pulling Russia out of the war.
events.punchline: The revolution eats the revolutionaries—now with Marxist seasoning.

events.title: 1917 Third Battle of Ypres begins
events.summary: British forces launch an offensive in Flanders, resulting in horrific casualties and minimal gains. The name 'Passchendaele' becomes synonymous with futility.
events.punchline: Men drown in mud while generals debate maps in dry rooms.

events.title: 1917 Balfour Declaration issued
events.summary: Britain expresses support for a 'national home for the Jewish people' in Palestine, laying groundwork for future conflict and alliances.
events.punchline: One letter, one sentence, one century of geopolitical migraines.

events.title: 1917 Espionage Act passed in the U.S.
events.summary: Congress enacts sweeping laws to suppress dissent and espionage, criminalizing anti-war speech and laying the foundation for future surveillance.
events.punchline: Free speech gets drafted into the war effort—under strict supervision.

events.title: 1917 Lenin returns to Russia
events.summary: With German help, Lenin travels from exile in Switzerland to Petrograd, setting the stage for the Bolshevik takeover.
events.punchline: Germany mails a revolutionary to Russia—no return address.

events.title: 1917 U.S. introduces Selective Service
events.summary: The U.S. begins drafting men for war, rapidly expanding its military and reshaping its role in global conflict.
events.punchline: Uncle Sam stops asking nicely.

events.title: 1917 First U.S. troops arrive in France
events.summary: American Expeditionary Forces land in Europe, marking the beginning of direct U.S. military involvement in the war.
events.punchline: Fresh boots hit French soil—wide-eyed, undertrained, and ready.

events.title: 1917 Germany begins planning Spring Offensive
events.summary: With Russia exiting the war, Germany prepares a massive push on the Western Front to break the stalemate before American forces arrive.
events.punchline: Germany rolls the dice one last time—before the fresh Americans flood the board.

events.title: 1917 Kerensky Offensive collapses
events.summary: Russia’s provisional government launches a final offensive against the Central Powers, but poor morale and Bolshevik agitation doom it to failure.
events.punchline: An army without a country tries to fight a war without a cause.

events.title: 1917 Battle of Cambrai showcases tank warfare
events.summary: British forces launch a surprise attack using hundreds of tanks, achieving initial success before German counterattacks reclaim ground.
events.punchline: Steel beasts break the line—until old tactics drag it back into the mud.

events.title: 1917 U.S. creates War Industries Board
events.summary: The U.S. government centralizes war production, coordinating industry to support the military and laying groundwork for future mobilization models.
events.punchline: Capitalism gets drafted—profits meet patriotism in the factory line.

events.title: 1917 Liberty Loan campaigns begin
events.summary: The U.S. Treasury launches massive public bond drives to finance the war, blending patriotism with financial pressure.
events.punchline: Buy a bond, fund a bullet—Wall Street joins the trenches.

events.title: 1917 Italy suffers defeat at Caporetto
events.summary: A combined Austro-German offensive crushes Italian forces, causing massive retreat and reshaping Allied strategy in the south.
events.punchline: The Alps echo with panic—Italy learns the hard way what a coordinated enemy looks like.

events.title: 1917 U.S. Army Air Service established
events.summary: The U.S. formalizes its military aviation branch, setting the stage for future air power doctrine and NATO’s eventual aerial backbone.
events.punchline: America takes to the skies—slowly, loudly, and with goggles.

events.title: 1917 Women join UK police forces
events.summary: With men at war, women begin serving in law enforcement roles, marking a shift in gender roles and public security.
events.punchline: The war opens doors—some with badges, some with batons.

events.title: 1917 U.S. Food Administration created
events.summary: Led by Herbert Hoover, the agency manages food production and conservation, pioneering logistics models later used in NATO operations.
events.punchline: Victory begins in the kitchen—Hoover makes calories strategic.

events.title: 1917 UK expands MI5 operations
events.summary: Britain’s domestic intelligence service intensifies counter-espionage efforts, laying groundwork for future NATO intelligence collaboration.
events.punchline: The spy game gets institutional—paranoia becomes protocol.

events.title: 1917 Zimmermann Telegram intercepted
events.summary: Germany proposes alliance with Mexico vs. US; UK intelligence leaks it, bringing America into European war.
events.punchline: Spycraft ensures US will never leave European security again.

events.title: 1918 German Spring Offensive begins
events.summary: Germany launches a massive assault on the Western Front, hoping to win the war before American forces arrive in full strength.
events.punchline: Germany throws everything forward—hoping the Allies blink before the doughboys land.

events.title: 1918 Second Battle of the Marne
events.summary: Allied forces, bolstered by fresh American troops, repel the last major German offensive, marking the turning point of the war.
events.punchline: The tide turns—America arrives, and Germany starts counting exits.

events.title: 1918 Treaty of Brest-Litovsk signed
events.summary: Russia exits the war, ceding massive territory to Germany and freeing up troops for the Western Front.
events.punchline: Russia trades land for peace—Germany gets breathing room and a ticking clock.

events.title: 1918 Battle of Amiens begins
events.summary: Allied forces launch a surprise offensive using tanks, aircraft, and coordinated infantry, breaking German lines and morale.
events.punchline: The war learns to coordinate—Germany learns to retreat.

events.title: 1918 Spanish Flu pandemic begins
events.summary: A deadly influenza virus spreads globally, killing tens of millions and overwhelming military and civilian systems.
events.punchline: The war ends—but the dying doesn’t.

events.title: 1918 Armistice ends World War I
events.summary: Germany signs an armistice with the Allies, ending fighting on the Western Front and marking the collapse of the Central Powers.
events.punchline: The guns fall silent—until the treaties start screaming.

events.title: 1918 Austria-Hungary collapses
events.summary: Internal revolts and military defeats shatter the empire, leading to its dissolution and the birth of new nations.
events.punchline: An empire dies—not with a bang, but with a dozen declarations of independence.

events.title: 1918 German Revolution begins
events.summary: Sailors mutiny, workers strike, and the monarchy collapses, leading to the creation of the Weimar Republic.
events.punchline: The Kaiser flees—Germany trades crowns for chaos.

events.title: 1918 Wilson announces Fourteen Points
events.summary: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson outlines principles for peace, including self-determination and collective security.
events.punchline: Idealism hits the battlefield—Europe nods politely, then ignores most of it.

events.title: 1918 Czechoslovakia declares independence
events.summary: The new nation emerges from the ruins of Austria-Hungary, marking a shift toward national self-determination in Central Europe.
events.punchline: A new flag rises—stitched from imperial scraps and hopeful slogans.

events.title: 1918 Finland's independence recognized
events.summary: Major powers formally acknowledge Finland’s break from Russia, marking a shift in Nordic geopolitics and future NATO alignment.
events.punchline: Finland steps out of Russia’s shadow—into a century of strategic balancing.

events.title: 1918 U.S. Employment Service established
events.summary: The U.S. creates a federal agency to coordinate labor during wartime, laying groundwork for future mobilization logistics.
events.punchline: Matching workers to war—bureaucracy becomes battlefield logistics.

events.title: 1918 Free Committee for German Workers Peace founded
events.summary: A small nationalist group forms in Munich, laying ideological groundwork for what will become the Nazi Party.
events.punchline: A fringe club with bad ideas—history will give it a megaphone.

events.title: 1918 USS Nevada enters service
events.summary: The U.S. Navy commissions the USS Nevada, the first battleship with triple gun turrets and oil-fired boilers, setting a new standard for naval power.
events.punchline: Steel, oil, and fire—America builds a floating fortress for the century ahead.

events.title: 1918 UK grants women limited voting rights
events.summary: British women over 30 gain the right to vote, a major step in democratic reform and post-war social restructuring.
events.punchline: The war gives women bullets and ballots—finally, one sticks.

events.title: 1918 U.S. launches air mail service
events.summary: The U.S. begins regular air mail delivery, advancing aviation logistics that will later support military operations.
events.punchline: Letters take flight—soon, bombs will follow.

events.title: 1918 Royal Air Force founded
events.summary: The UK merges its army and navy air services into the RAF, creating the world’s first independent air force.
events.punchline: The sky gets its own army—future wars will look up.

events.title: 1918 U.S. National Defense Council expands
events.summary: The council coordinates industrial production, transportation, and communication for war, modeling future NATO logistics frameworks.
events.punchline: War becomes a spreadsheet—efficiency joins the arsenal.

events.title: 1918 U.S. Army Signal Corps expands operations
events.summary: The Signal Corps deploys new radio and telegraph systems across Europe, pioneering battlefield communications.
events.punchline: The war gets wired—messages move faster than men.

events.title: 1918 U.S. Army Medical Corps modernized
events.summary: Facing the Spanish Flu and battlefield injuries, the U.S. revamps its medical corps, introducing mobile hospitals and triage systems.
events.punchline: Healing becomes tactical—triage joins the chain of command.

events.title: 1919 Treaty of Versailles signed
events.summary: The Allies impose harsh terms on Germany, redrawing borders, demanding reparations, and planting the seeds of future conflict.
events.punchline: Peace is signed with a pen dipped in resentment.

events.title: 1919 League of Nations established
events.summary: The first global intergovernmental organization for peace and collective security is born—flawed, but foundational.
events.punchline: A noble idea—undermined by absence and ambition.

events.title: 1919 Weimar Republic declared in Germany
events.summary: Germany transitions to a democratic government under immense pressure, economic collapse, and revolutionary threat.
events.punchline: Democracy arrives—fragile, hated, and already bleeding.

events.title: 1919 Polish-Soviet War begins
events.summary: Poland and Soviet Russia clash over borderlands, testing the postwar order and previewing future East-West tensions.
events.punchline: A new Poland fights a new Russia—neither knows the rules yet.

events.title: 1919 May Fourth Movement erupts in China
events.summary: Chinese students protest the Treaty of Versailles and foreign domination, sparking a nationalist and cultural awakening.
events.punchline: China reads the treaty—and starts rewriting its future.

events.title: 1919 Hungarian Soviet Republic declared
events.summary: Communists seize power in Hungary, creating a short-lived regime that alarms neighboring states and the West.
events.punchline: A red experiment in the heart of Europe—quickly quarantined.

events.title: 1919 Greco-Turkish War begins
events.summary: Greek forces land in Anatolia, sparking a brutal conflict that will reshape Turkey and its military doctrine.
events.punchline: The empire’s corpse twitches—Greece tries to carve its initials.

events.title: 1919 Irish War of Independence begins
events.summary: The IRA launches a guerrilla campaign against British rule, marking the start of a long, bitter struggle.
events.punchline: Ireland trades ballots for bullets—London barely flinches.

events.title: 1919 Versailles Treaty bans German air force
events.summary: Germany is forbidden from maintaining an air force, a clause that will be ignored and reversed within two decades.
events.punchline: Grounded by treaty—until the Luftwaffe takes off.

events.title: 1919 U.S. Senate rejects League of Nations
events.summary: Despite Wilson’s efforts, the U.S. refuses to join the League, weakening its credibility and foreshadowing isolationism.
events.punchline: America builds the clubhouse—then walks away from the door.

events.title: 1919 Treaty of Neuilly signed
events.summary: Bulgaria is forced to cede territory and pay reparations, deepening regional instability and resentment.
events.punchline: Bulgaria gets the bill—resentment is tax-free.

events.title: 1919 Treaty of Saint-Germain signed
events.summary: Austria loses territory and recognition as an empire, birthing new states and nationalist tensions.
events.punchline: Austria downsizes—history calls it peace, Vienna calls it humiliation.

events.title: 1919 Treaty of Trianon drafted
events.summary: Hungary’s borders are redrawn, losing two-thirds of its territory and sparking long-term ethnic tensions.
events.punchline: Hungary wakes up smaller—its anger doesn’t.

events.title: 1919 UK allows women to sit in Parliament
events.summary: The Sex Disqualification (Removal) Act opens the door for women to hold public office, reshaping British governance.
events.punchline: The House gets new voices—finally, some without mustaches.

events.title: 1919 U.S. Army Air Service expands operations
events.summary: The U.S. increases funding and scope for military aviation, laying groundwork for future air dominance.
events.punchline: The sky becomes strategy—America starts climbing.

events.title: 1919 U.S. Navy develops long-range radio
events.summary: Naval engineers improve radio transmission range, revolutionizing fleet coordination and future command systems.
events.punchline: The ocean gets ears—orders now travel faster than ships.

events.title: 1919 RAF establishes intelligence division
events.summary: The Royal Air Force formalizes aerial reconnaissance and intelligence gathering, shaping future surveillance doctrine.
events.punchline: Eyes in the sky—before satellites, there were sketchpads and binoculars.

events.title: 1919 U.S. hosts military-industrial coordination meetings
events.summary: Government and industry leaders meet to discuss postwar production and defense readiness, foreshadowing future alliances.
events.punchline: The war ends—contracts begin.

events.title: 1919 Imperial War Museum founded
events.summary: Britain establishes a museum to preserve the memory and lessons of the Great War, shaping public understanding of conflict.
events.punchline: History gets curated—war becomes an exhibit.

events.title: 1919 U.S. creates Veterans Bureau
events.summary: The U.S. establishes a federal agency to support returning soldiers, institutionalizing care for military personnel.
events.punchline: The war ends—bureaucracy begins.

events.title: 1920 League of Nations officially formed
events.summary: The first global organization for collective security is established in Geneva, aiming to prevent future wars through diplomacy and arbitration.
events.punchline: The world builds a peace machine—without half the mechanics.

events.title: 1920 U.S. Senate rejects League of Nations again
events.summary: Despite Wilson’s vision, the U.S. refuses to join the League, weakening its authority and signaling a retreat into isolationism.
events.punchline: America builds the clubhouse—then locks the door from the outside.

events.title: 1920 Polish-Soviet War escalates
events.summary: Poland launches a bold offensive toward Kyiv, clashing with Soviet forces in a brutal campaign that tests postwar borders and ideologies.
events.punchline: Poland charges east—history watches with popcorn and dread.

events.title: 1920 Treaty of Sèvres signed
events.summary: The Ottoman Empire is carved up by the Allies, triggering nationalist backlash and the rise of Turkish resistance.
events.punchline: The empire gets diced—Ankara starts sharpening knives.

events.title: 1920 Turkish War of Independence begins
events.summary: Mustafa Kemal leads nationalist forces against occupying powers, rejecting the Treaty of Sèvres and reshaping Turkey’s future.
events.punchline: The empire dies—Anatolia refuses to attend the funeral.

events.title: 1920 U.S. Red Scare intensifies
events.summary: Fear of communism leads to mass arrests, deportations, and surveillance, shaping future domestic security doctrine.
events.punchline: America sees red—then starts blacklisting.

events.title: 1920 France takes mandate over Syria and Lebanon
events.summary: Under League authority, France assumes control of former Ottoman territories, sparking resistance and reshaping Middle Eastern geopolitics.
events.punchline: The map gets new lines—none drawn by locals.

events.title: 1920 Battle of Warsaw
events.summary: Polish forces repel the Soviet advance in a dramatic counteroffensive, hailed as the 'Miracle on the Vistula.'
events.punchline: Poland punches back—history calls it a miracle, Moscow calls it a mess.

events.title: 1920 RAF tests air control doctrine in Iraq
events.summary: British forces use aircraft to suppress uprisings in Mesopotamia, pioneering a controversial model of imperial policing.
events.punchline: The empire learns to bomb its problems from above.

events.title: 1920 U.S. begins licensing radio stations
events.summary: The Department of Commerce starts regulating radio frequencies, laying the foundation for military and civilian communications infrastructure.
events.punchline: The airwaves get rules—before they get encrypted.

events.title: 1920 UK establishes Air Ministry
events.summary: Britain creates a dedicated government department to oversee military aviation, formalizing air power as a strategic domain.
events.punchline: The sky gets its own ministry—war learns to fly with paperwork.

events.title: 1920 U.S. restructures Council on National Defense
events.summary: The council shifts focus from wartime production to peacetime preparedness, maintaining links between government and industry.
events.punchline: The war ends—coordination stays. Bureaucracy never demobilizes.

events.title: 1920 Iraqi revolt against British rule
events.summary: Widespread uprisings challenge British control in Mesopotamia, forcing a shift from direct rule to mandate governance.
events.punchline: The empire learns that mandates don’t come with consent.

events.title: 1920 U.S. amends National Defense Act
events.summary: Congress expands the Army and formalizes the National Guard’s role, reinforcing federal control over military readiness.
events.punchline: The Guard gets federalized—readiness becomes regulation.

events.title: 1920 UK begins building Imperial Wireless Chain
events.summary: Britain launches a global radio network to connect its colonies, enhancing strategic communication and control.
events.punchline: The empire gets wired—control travels at the speed of signal.

events.title: 1920 U.S. expands air mail service
events.summary: The Post Office Department formalizes air mail routes, boosting aviation infrastructure and pilot training.
events.punchline: Mail takes flight—training pilots for wars they don’t know are coming.

events.title: 1920 RAF begins aerial mapping missions
events.summary: British aircraft conduct systematic aerial surveys, revolutionizing cartography and military planning.
events.punchline: The world gets photographed—strategy starts with altitude.

events.title: 1920 UK formalizes Imperial General Staff
events.summary: Britain centralizes military planning across its empire, coordinating defense strategy among dominions and colonies.
events.punchline: The empire gets a brain—strategy goes imperial.

events.title: 1920 U.S. expands Army Signal School
events.summary: The Signal Corps increases training in radio, telegraphy, and encryption, laying groundwork for modern battlefield communications.
events.punchline: The battlefield gets bandwidth—war learns to whisper in code.

events.title: 1920 UK forms Committee for Scientific Research in Defense
events.summary: Britain establishes a formal body to coordinate scientific innovation for military use, foreshadowing future defense R&D institutions.
events.punchline: War gets a lab—ideas become weapons on paper first.

events.title: 1921 Washington Naval Conference opens
events.summary: Nine nations gather in Washington D.C. to negotiate naval disarmament and Pacific security, marking the first major arms control summit.
events.punchline: The world tries to shrink its navies—before egos sink the treaties.

events.title: 1921 Irish Free State formally established
events.summary: The Anglo-Irish Treaty creates a self-governing dominion, ending the war of independence and reshaping British imperial structure.
events.punchline: Ireland gets a state—Britain gets a headache with a flag.

events.title: 1921 First Battle of İnönü
events.summary: Turkish nationalist forces clash with Greek troops, marking a key moment in the Turkish War of Independence.
events.punchline: The new Turkey flexes—Greece gets a preview of the retreat.

events.title: 1921 Treaty of Moscow signed
events.summary: Soviet Russia and Turkey sign a treaty defining borders and rejecting Western-imposed settlements, signaling a new axis of defiance.
events.punchline: Two empires in ruins shake hands—against the mapmakers.

events.title: 1921 U.S. Navy creates Bureau of Aeronautics
events.summary: The Navy establishes a dedicated aviation bureau, formalizing aircraft development and strategy within naval operations.
events.punchline: The Navy gets wings—war learns to fly from the sea.

events.title: 1921 UK forms Air Defense Committee
events.summary: Britain establishes a formal body to study aerial threats and defense strategies, anticipating future air wars.
events.punchline: The sky gets a committee—before it gets bombed.

events.title: 1921 U.S. tests radio-guided torpedo
events.summary: Naval engineers experiment with remote-controlled torpedoes, an early step toward autonomous weapons systems.
events.punchline: The torpedo gets a signal—war starts whispering through wires.

events.title: 1921 Second Battle of İnönü
events.summary: Turkish forces repel another Greek offensive, solidifying nationalist control and boosting morale.
events.punchline: Greece tries again—Turkey answers with trenches and pride.

events.title: 1921 RAF expands operations in Middle East
events.summary: British air forces increase patrols and bombing missions in Iraq and Palestine, refining imperial air control doctrine.
events.punchline: The empire flies over its problems—sometimes drops solutions.

events.summary: To enforce reparations, French and Belgian troops occupy Germany’s industrial heartland, triggering strikes and economic collapse.

events.summary: The German mark collapses, with prices doubling every few days. Citizens carry cash in wheelbarrows and burn it for heat.

events.title: 1923 Republic of Turkey declared
events.summary: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk abolishes the Ottoman sultanate and proclaims the Republic of Turkey, launching sweeping reforms.

events.title: 1923 Great Kantō Earthquake devastates Japan

events.title: 1923 Italy consolidates Libya

events.title: 1926 Germany joins the League of Nations

events.punchline: The campus gets camo—strategy starts with textbooks.

events.title: 1927 League of Nations expands membership
events.summary: Several nations, including Venezuela and Iraq, join the League, reflecting growing global interest in collective diplomacy.
events.punchline: The table gets longer—peace gets more signatures, fewer guarantees.

events.title: 1928 Kellogg–Briand Pact signed
events.summary: Sixty-two nations agree to renounce war as a tool of national policy, marking a high point of interwar idealism and diplomatic theater.
events.punchline: War gets banned—generals quietly sharpen their pencils.

events.title: 1928 Alexander Fleming discovers penicillin
events.summary: Fleming’s accidental discovery of the world’s first true antibiotic revolutionizes medicine and battlefield survival.
events.punchline: Mold saves lives—war wounds get a second chance.

events.title: 1928 Warlord Zhang Zuolin assassinated
events.summary: Japanese agents bomb the train of Manchurian warlord Zhang Zuolin, destabilizing northern China and accelerating Japanese expansion.
events.punchline: The train explodes—Manchuria starts unraveling.

events.title: 1928 Okeechobee hurricane devastates Florida
events.summary: A Category 5 hurricane kills thousands across Florida and the Caribbean, exposing infrastructure vulnerabilities and prompting federal response reforms.
events.punchline: The storm hits—governments scramble to catch up.

events.title: 1928 Italy completes colonization of Libya
events.summary: The Senussi resistance collapses, and Italy consolidates full control over Libya, marking the end of major local opposition.
events.punchline: The desert goes quiet—Rome redraws the map.

events.title: 1928 Great Thames Flood strikes London
events.summary: A catastrophic flood kills 14 and damages key infrastructure, prompting future investment in flood defenses like the Thames Barrier.
events.punchline: The river rises—London learns to build walls.

events.title: 1928 Women compete in Olympic track events
events.summary: The Amsterdam Olympics include women’s track and field for the first time, marking a milestone in gender equality in sport.
events.punchline: The starting gun fires—history runs in new shoes.

events.title: 1928 Stalin’s secretary defects
events.summary: Boris Bazhanov escapes the USSR via Iran, becoming the first high-ranking Soviet insider to expose Stalin’s inner circle.
events.punchline: Secrets cross borders—Stalin starts locking doors tighter.

events.title: 1928 Austrian customs intercept covert arms shipment
events.summary: Officials discover mislabeled machine gun parts en route from Italy to Czechoslovakia, sparking diplomatic tensions over clandestine rearmament.
events.punchline: The crates lie—Europe starts checking its neighbors’ basements.

events.title: 1928 Mickey Mouse debuts in 'Steamboat Willie'
events.summary: Walt Disney’s animated short introduces Mickey Mouse, launching a cultural icon and a new era in propaganda-capable media.
events.punchline: The mouse squeaks—soft power gets a cartoon face.

events.title: 1928 Germany begins covert panzer development
events.summary: Despite Versailles restrictions, Germany secretly funds tank research in cooperation with Soviet engineers, laying groundwork for future armored warfare.
events.punchline: The blueprint hides in plain sight—steel dreams wait for ignition.

events.title: 1928 Turkey launches national rail expansion
events.summary: Atatürk’s government begins a massive railway project to unify the country and support industrial and military logistics.
events.punchline: Steel tracks stitch the republic—strategy rides the rails.

events.title: 1928 USSR begins border fortification program
events.summary: The Soviet Union starts building defensive structures along western borders, anticipating future conflict with Europe.
events.punchline: Concrete meets paranoia—Stalin starts drawing lines in stone.

events.title: 1928 Japan increases naval spending
events.summary: The Imperial Japanese Navy receives a major budget boost, accelerating shipbuilding and signaling Pacific ambitions.
events.punchline: The fleet grows—Asia starts watching the horizon.

events.title: 1928 Brazil expands military aviation
events.summary: Brazil increases investment in aircraft production and pilot training, aiming to modernize its defense capabilities.
events.punchline: The jungle gets altitude—Brazil starts sketching its airspace.

events.title: 1928 Iran launches police reform
events.summary: Reza Shah centralizes law enforcement, creating a national police force to enforce modernization and suppress dissent.
events.punchline: The badge gets sharper—order becomes a uniformed doctrine.

events.title: 1928 Ethiopia expands military academies
events.summary: Haile Selassie increases funding for officer training, preparing the country for future defense against colonial threats.
events.punchline: The classroom gets camo—Africa starts thinking in formations.

events.title: 1928 USS Langley conducts night flight trials
events.summary: The U.S. Navy tests nighttime carrier operations, advancing tactics for future 24-hour naval air warfare.
events.punchline: Darkness becomes doctrine—war learns to fly blind.

events.title: 1928 Romania expands border fortifications
events.summary: Amid rising regional tensions, Romania begins reinforcing its borders with bunkers and artillery emplacements.
events.punchline: The frontier gets teeth—Bucharest starts bracing for echoes.

events.title: 1928 League of Nations approves global disarmament conference
events.summary: The League votes to convene a major disarmament summit, reflecting growing pressure to reduce arms amid rising militarization.
events.punchline: Peace gets a podium—militaries send observers with notebooks.

events.title: 1929 Wall Street Crash triggers global depression
events.summary: The U.S. stock market collapses, wiping out billions and plunging the world into economic turmoil that will fuel extremism and militarism.
events.punchline: The market crashes—ideologies rise from the rubble.

events.title: 1929 Lateran Treaty signed between Italy and Vatican
events.summary: Mussolini and Pope Pius XI sign a treaty recognizing Vatican City as an independent state, resolving decades of tension between church and state.
events.punchline: The altar and the fascist handshake—Rome gets spiritual leverage.

events.title: 1929 USSR launches First Five-Year Plan
events.summary: Stalin initiates a massive industrialization and collectivization campaign, transforming the Soviet economy and military capacity.
events.punchline: Steel meets ideology—Russia starts building its war machine.

events.title: 1929 Germany expands covert aircraft research
events.summary: Despite Versailles restrictions, Germany increases funding for aviation technology, laying groundwork for future Luftwaffe capabilities.
events.punchline: The skies get secret blueprints—Germany starts sketching altitude.

events.title: 1929 Iran adopts modern penal code
events.summary: Reza Shah introduces a secular legal framework, replacing Islamic criminal law and aligning Iran with European legal standards.
events.punchline: The courtroom gets Western walls—tradition watches from the hallway.

events.title: 1929 Japan increases military spending
events.summary: The Japanese government boosts funding for army and navy expansion, signaling growing ambitions in East Asia.
events.punchline: The budget grows—Asia starts watching the horizon again.

events.title: 1929 Brazil expands military aviation academy
events.summary: Brazil increases investment in pilot training and aircraft production, continuing its push toward regional air power.
events.punchline: The cockpit gets crowded—Brazil starts thinking in formations.

events.title: 1929 Ethiopia strengthens border patrol units
events.summary: Haile Selassie increases funding for frontier defense, anticipating colonial pressure from Italy and regional instability.
events.punchline: The border gets binoculars—Selassie starts counting shadows.

events.title: 1929 Romania signs Balkan Pact
events.summary: Romania joins Greece and Yugoslavia in a regional alliance aimed at mutual defense and resisting revisionist powers.
events.punchline: The Balkans link arms—history watches with a smirk.

events.title: 1929 USS Langley tests aircraft recovery systems
events.summary: The U.S. Navy experiments with arresting gear and deck protocols, refining carrier operations for future combat readiness.
events.punchline: Landing becomes choreography—war rehearses its next act.

events.title: 1929 Ethiopia expands military logistics network
events.summary: Haile Selassie invests in supply chains and transport infrastructure to support Ethiopia’s growing army amid rising colonial threats.
events.punchline: The empire gets wheels—strategy starts with crates and camels.

events.title: 1929 Turkey reinforces eastern border defenses
events.summary: Atatürk’s government builds new fortifications along the eastern frontier, anticipating instability in neighboring regions.
events.punchline: The frontier gets concrete—Ankara starts listening for echoes.

events.title: 1929 Iran begins national airfield construction
events.summary: Reza Shah launches a program to build airfields across Iran, laying the foundation for future military and civilian aviation.
events.punchline: The desert gets runways—Tehran starts sketching altitude.

events.title: 1929 Japan expands military intelligence operations
